lullaby.optimalKey: Major keys (C, F, G) or minor keys (Am, Dm) - avoid complex keys
lullaby.melodicRange: Narrow range (octave or less), stay in easy vocal register

rhythmicFeatures.meter: Triple meter (3/4, 6/8) or duple with rocking feel (4/4 with swing)
rhythmicFeatures.pattern: Gentle, swaying, waltz-like or rocking motion

structure.duration: 2-3 minutes, but designed for looping indefinitely

lyricContent.avoid: Stimulating or scary images, complex narratives, questions
lyricContent.repetition: Extremely high - same phrases multiple times

vocalsStyle.dynamics: Mostly soft (p to mp), occasional gentle swells

acousticConsiderations.frequency: Avoid very high frequencies, focus on mid-range
acousticConsiderations.whitePinkNoise: Optional very soft background nature sounds

ageSpecificAdaptations.0-6months: Simpler melodies, more repetitive, softer dynamics
ageSpecificAdaptations.1-6years: Can have simple story element, still very calming

exampleStructure.verse1: Twinkle twinkle little star, How I wonder what you are...
exampleStructure.verse2: Up above the world so high, Like a diamond in the sky...
exampleStructure.verse3: Twinkle twinkle little star, How I wonder what you are...

scientificBasis: 60-80 BPM matches mother's resting heartbeat
Familiar from womb experience
Triple meter mimics rocking/swaying motion
Repetition provides predictability and security
Soft vocals activate parasympathetic nervous system (calming)

educationalSong.optimalKey: C Major, G Major, D Major (easy to sing)
educationalSong.melodicRange: Child's vocal range (D4 to D5 typically)

vocalsStyle.dynamics: Moderate to moderately loud (mf to f)

ageSpecificAdaptations.4-6years: Full alphabet, numbers to 20+, complex concepts

exampleStructure.chorus: Learning letters is so fun, We'll sing them all, every one!

scientificBasis: Music activates multiple brain regions for memory
Rhythm supports pattern recognition and math
Melody aids long-term retention (superior to spoken words)
Repetition strengthens neural pathways
Multimodal learning (hearing + singing + moving) most effective

lyricContent.imperatives: Command form encourages action (Jump! Clap! Dance!)
lyricContent.repetition: Moderate - enough to learn, varied enough for interest

vocalsStyle.dynamics: Loud (f to ff), varying for effect

ageSpecificAdaptations.1-2years: Simple movements (clap, stomp, wave), slower tempo (100-120 BPM)
ageSpecificAdaptations.2-3years: Basic dance moves, body part touches, moderate tempo (110-130 BPM)
ageSpecificAdaptations.3-4years: Complex movements, coordination challenges, upbeat (120-140 BPM)
ageSpecificAdaptations.4-6years: Dance routines, sequences, games, fast tempo (130-160 BPM)

exampleStructure.verse1: Wake up, wake up, it's a brand new day! Time to jump and shout and play!
exampleStructure.chorus: Clap your hands! (clap clap) Stomp your feet! (stomp stomp) Dance around to the beat beat beat!
exampleStructure.verse2: Stretch up high, reach for the sky! Now bend down low, here we go!
exampleStructure.bridge: Now we're gonna freeze! (silence) Now we GO GO GO!

scientificBasis: Fast tempo increases heart rate and alertness
Movement songs build gross motor skills
Physical activity releases dopamine and endorphins
Music-movement integration enhances brain development
Energizing music effective for transitions

lyricContent.positive framing: State what IS, not what isn't
lyricContent.repetition: Each affirmation repeated 3-6 times per song

vocalsStyle.dynamics: Moderate to strong (mf to f), confident

ageSpecificAdaptations.0-2years: Second person ('You are loved'), parent sings to child
ageSpecificAdaptations.2-3years: Transition to first person, simple concepts
ageSpecificAdaptations.3-4years: First person, multiple affirmations per song

exampleStructure.verse1: I am special, I am me, I'm the best that I can be
exampleStructure.chorus: I am loved, I am strong, I am right where I belong (repeat 2x)
exampleStructure.verse2: I am brave, I can try, I can reach up to the sky
exampleStructure.bridge: Every day I'm learning, Every day I'm growing

scientificBasis: Repeated positive messages create neural pathways
First-person affirmations more powerful than second-person
Music + affirmation = dual encoding for stronger memory
Builds self-concept and resilience
Activates reward centers when internalized

storySong.purpose: Tell narrative, teach moral, cultural story
storySong.optimalKey: Major or minor based on story mood
storySong.melodicRange: Variable based on character and emotion

structure.arc: Beginning, middle, end with clear resolution

lyricContent.narrative: Clear story with characters, problem, solution
lyricContent.characterVoices: Different melodies or styles for different characters
lyricContent.repetition: Chorus provides grounding, verses advance story

ageSpecificAdaptations.3-4years: Simple problem-solution, animals or children characters
ageSpecificAdaptations.4-6years: Complex plot, moral lessons, fantasy elements

exampleStructure.verse1: Once there was a little bear who lived inside a cave...(Introduce character)
exampleStructure.chorus: Little bear, little bear, what will you do? Adventures waiting just for you!
exampleStructure.verse2: One day he heard a sound outside...(Problem arises)
exampleStructure.bridge: He gathered all his courage and...(Climax)
exampleStructure.verse3: And that's how little bear made friends...(Resolution)

scientificBasis: Narrative structure aids memory and comprehension
Stories build empathy and perspective-taking
Music enhances emotional connection to narrative
Teaches cause-effect relationships
Cultural stories build identity

lyricContent.empowerment: Gives child tools to handle situations

ageSpecificAdaptations.2-3years: Basic emotions (happy, sad, mad), simple solutions
ageSpecificAdaptations.3-4years: More emotions, basic social skills (sharing, turn-taking)

exampleStructure.verse1: When I feel angry, my face gets hot, My hands get tight, I want what I want
exampleStructure.chorus: I can take deep breaths, 1-2-3, Count to ten and calm down, calm down me
exampleStructure.verse2: When I feel sad, I want to cry, That's okay, I'll tell you why
exampleStructure.chorus: I can talk about my feelings, yes I can, I can ask for a hug or hold someone's hand
exampleStructure.outro: All my feelings are okay, I have tools to help me every day

scientificBasis: Naming emotions helps regulate them
Songs provide emotional scripts children can follow
Music activates emotional centers + cognitive centers simultaneously
Repeated practice through song builds social skills
Songs as coping tools in challenging moments

productionQuality.authenticity: Real instruments preferred over heavy synthesis (especially for young children)
